Hi all ECB'ers,

Just looking for advice on Druid builds. I thought it would be time I gave this class a serious try on a playthrough through Aielund (or other modules - if you suggest I will certainly give it a go!)

I wanted to try to create a very good caster, which would pretty much mean very high Druid levels.

I've read Monk is very important for shapeshifter builds and I dont want to compromise this so I have included 1 monk level after you get access to forms, also for a tumble and listen dump. I thought taking a couple more levels of Rogue for dumps of skills points, which the Druid seems to accumulate in abundance. Useful skills I wanted to get were Concentration, Heal, Tumble, Spellcraft, Listen, Spot, Persuade and Lore.

I've read through a few of Maximillan Kane's posts when designing this, including Guide to the Druid Class. He also suggested getting 1 rank in Open Lock so that if you are shifted to an Air Elemental you can pick locks.

I'm also curious as to the Shapechange spell, which is a level 9 druid spell. It hasn't drawn a lot of attention or love as far as I can see. Max's guide to Druids seem to suggest the best shapes you play with are your wildshapes (ie Bear), then elementals (ie. Water Elemental), then skill Dragon Shape between level 30-36 to turn into a dragon. He seemed to imply here is a gap between level 20 and 30-36 where your forms are very weak until you get the Dragon Shape feat. Why not use the Shapechange spell, which allows a Red Dragon form (albeit not as strong) or a Golem form which allows tremendous immunities? Is it because their AB or AC is bad or something?

I've avoided taking Zen Archery given I'm going to shapechange into other forms for hand to hand combat

Max seems to think Conjuration is the best spell focus school so I have taken feats in that. I think that Max also mentioned it is best you 'tank' while your animal companion does damage - I took improved expertise at level 1 and Cons 14 to reflect this. 

I also tried to get Dragon Shape as soon as possible (level 30).

My reflex save also seems to suck but I guess I'm not playing a Paladin or Blackguard build anymore so I have to get used to it :)

Anyway, here is my build - I would love any comments on improvements before I start to play it in game :) I haven't played Druid before, just read a few guides which are out there. So I'm curious to hear what you think.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: My philosophy for druid caster builds is different than most & you can read about it on the druid build that I did in the "yardstick thread". Apart from that, I think the best 8 feats for pre-epic are: sf: conjuration, gsf: conjuration, sf: necromancy, gsf: necromancy, extend spell, empower spell, blind-fight & ic: unarmed strike. The last two can change depending on what do you want from your build, how many druid levels it has & how melee-oriented you want to be but they are solid choice regardless. You do not need penetration feats with 37 druid levels unless you expect to do PvP or you know there are very high MR enemies on the module that you play on.

By the way I am super glad I took that single level of Monk at 7 - it just made everything much easier... 10 tumble (+2AC) and 10 listen the icing on the cake as well.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Just an update. I thought I would post I found a possible answer to my own questions. 

RE Shapechange spell and Heavy Armor Proficiency feat ?useful for druid characters.

When polymorphed via feats such as wildshape and elemental form, only the magical properties of the helm, armor and shield slot are transferred. The base AC from items is not transferred. So you could wear mundane clothing or mundane full platemail plus mundane tower shield and the AC the polymorph gains is the same (zero). If you have an +5AC shield and +5AC armor this mean +5 AC polymorph AC as only the highest AC value is transferred. Whereas if you had that same +5AC Shield and Robes of the Old Order (damage reduction +1 soak 5 damage), you would have +5AC as a polymorph, plus the damage reduction. Therefore heavy armor proficiency provides no value to the polymorphed druid, unless one wishes to obtain the magical properties from a particular piece of heavy armor, and in that particular situation, there are probably better feats to take anyway which Valefor has outlined in detail.  Amulets, rings, belts, gloves and cloaks magical properties do not transfer to polymorphs. Bonus spells from additional wisdom (or Int/Cha if you are a wizard/sorcerer) from these items are lost when polymorphing so cast them as buffs before you do polymorph.

When polymophed via spells, such as Shapechange as far as I can see there is no such transfer of such magical properties from the helm, armor or shield at all or any items. Even though you are a big bad red dragon if you have powerful magical properties on helm, armor and/or shield slots it could be more advantageous to still transform into an elemental or greater elemental than use shapechange to turn into a dragon. I haven't got to level 17 Druid, which is when you get access to Lvl 9 spells to test it out in a practical sense in game. I can update this post once I get a chance to.

Anyway I thought I would share what I learned by playing the druid class, reading the Wiki (https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Polymorph) and testing it in game with the PGCC Module v4.3 (https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... ered-igipe). The mechanics of NWN 1 are so complex and subtle it is both beautiful and challenging to understand.

Orion2019 wrote: Heavy Armor Proficiency feat ?
You do not get the base armour class of the armour as you noted but the reason why it's good to have this (if you have spare feats) is because you can now use all available options to get the best possible combination of abilities from them.
For example, you might find a red dragon armour & want to use the fire resistance from it, etc.

The mechanics of NWN 1 are so complex and subtle it is both beautiful and challenging to understand.
Neverwinter Nights mechanic's are a crude approximation of the real 3rd edition rules, many things have been altered & others have been completely erased or missing entirely. Still, you have to remember that the 3rd edition ruleset is the most complex out of all editions of Dungeons & Dragons by far & the most inovative as well, it was nearly impossible by that time, to transfer everything the rules had 
to offer into a computer game. And yet, this is one of the best games ever created for true RPG fans.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yes, there are options in 3rd edition that player characters never had before or after this.

There is a detailed line of sight rules, so that players know what their characters see & can target with their spells/attacks.

The round is 6 seconds instead of abstract 1-minute from previous editions. There are 5-foot steps (a pain in the butt of any DM), difficult terrain rules, reactions & maneuvers like trip (knockdown), faint, disarm, bull-rush, overrun & sunder.

Then there is "reach", which was never detailed before & previously all monsters assumed to be engaged with the PCs in arbitrary distances but here a Titan wielding a polearm could have 30-feet reach & with combat reflexes feat could take attacks of opportunity against anyone engaging him long before they reach him. About the only thing simplified from previous editions was Initiative which is a downgrade from 2nd editions masterpiece but better by a longshot from 1st-editions convoluted system.

I would be happy to teach you some PnP but I'm afraid you are a long way from Athens, Empyre.
